oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A Map of Clifton Park, also Chenendahomie, 1765
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
The original map shows Canastigione and Clifton Park Land Patents, with western boundary of Halfmoon Patent. The original map reads "Laid out by the Commissioners, Jacob A. Ten Eyck, Volkert P. Douw, Abram Ten Broeck."
This print was created by Howard Becker on 3-24-1953. A list of names at bottom left corresponds to numbers drawn on the map to show the location of each individual's home. Becker's print was made from a 1923 copy of the original, with the signature of Theodore Gailer visible at bottom.
Land patents were the legal documentation showing the transfer of government land to citizens.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ten Eyck, Jacob A.; Douw, Volkert P.; Ten Broeck, Abram

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dunsbach Ferry docked on the Mohawk River
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of several men, horses, and carriages crossing the Mohawk River via the ferry at Dunsbach Ferry NY. One of the carriages bears the sign "Miller House, Cohoes." The tall poles on the ferry helped to keep the cables from swinging over the horses' heads. A small oar boat is visible at the river bank. The original photograph is affixed to a scrapbook page; an additional image of the ferry party (IAB00068) is below it on the same page.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clutes Dry Dock, Erie Canal, Forts Ferry, NY, c. 1890
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of the dry dock drained of water. Men stand on the closed gates of the dry dock, Nicholas Clute's store is on the left. The Erie Canal is visible in the background. Canal boats needing repair would enter the dry dock, which would be drained of water and the boats would be held on cradles - visible in the foreground of this photo. Workers could then access the boats to repair them.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mr. Bell's sand team and men, Forts Ferry, NY, c. 1890
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of work horses with men in wagon, women are visible on the porch of the house in the background. On reverse of photograph Adam J. Van Vranken wrote "Aunt G. [Gertrude Van Vranken Lansing], Miss Bell, Uncle John, and men." The mining of molding sand was a major industry in Clifton Park during the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. The sand was shipped out on canal boats or trains to foundaries where it was used to produce cast iron. Original photograph is mounted, scanned image has cropped out mounting board.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Refreshment Stand, Rexford Park, Rexford, NY, c. 1920
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black-and-white photograph of a refreshment stand, situated in front of the park hotel, at the Rexford Park amusement park in Rexford, NY. The stand sold lemonade for 10 cents as well as frankfurters. Several men mill about the stand. Beyond the stand to the right is the park hotel and restaurant. Several people stand on the staircase leading to the hotel porch. The park dance hall and rollerskating rink is partially visible behind the refreshment stand at the left edge of the photograph. A handwritten note on the back of the photograph labels it C-477 and dates it to 'about 1920.'

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ice Cream Parlor, Rexford Park, Rexford, NY, c. 1920
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of the ice cream parlor and its staff, at Rexford Park, in Rexford, NY. The park was originally known as Luna Park when it opened in 1906, then renamed Dolle's Park when Fred Dolle acquired it in 1911. It became Rexford Park in 1916 when the park came under new management, and it closed in 1933.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Riders on the Whip, Rexford Park amusement park, Rexford, NY, 1926
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph is a reprint of an original image. Reprint is dated May 1997. The photograph shows two groups of three women riding the Whip, an amusement park ride at Rexford Park. The women were attending the concessionaries clambake. Visible in the background from left to right are Spill the Milk, hall of mirrors, and the aerial swing. The park was originally known as Luna Park when it opened in 1906, then renamed Dolle's Park when Fred Dolle acquired it in 1911. It became Rexford Park in 1916 when the park came under new management, and it closed in 1933.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Amusement parks; Amusement rides; Roller coasters;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nathan Garnsey House, Route 146, Rexford, NY, 1891
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Reprint of original photograph showing the Centennial Anniversary of the Nathan Garnsey House in 1891. The house was occupied in 1891 by Henry C. DeLong, Millie Smalley DeLong and their family. Standing to the right of the large tree beneath the welcome sign is Mille Smalley DeLong, granddaughter of John Smalley and Hannah Barnes-niece of Nathan Garnsey Jr. She is next to her husband, Henry. To his right is an unknown man, then LeGrand Rexford, and Cyrus W. Rexford. Emmor J. Caldwell is seated in the second row, sixth from left, and in front of him to the left is Garnsey Caldwell, who is seated in the first row fourth from left. The other people pictured are friends and relatives, many are descendants of Nathan Garnsey who built the house in 1791. Route 146 appears in the foreground as a one-lane dirt road.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Platt, Charles

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Reprint of an original photograph. Image scanned to remove white border. Photograph shows the Cyrus Rexford House at Route 146 and Riverview Road in Rexford, NY. Posed in front of the house are: seated in the wheelchair, Hannah Minerva Hollister Rexford; her daughter Fanny Rexford Graves stands in the center; and Fanny's daughters Rita and Hollie are on either side of Fanny. This grand Victorian mansion was built by store owner, postmaster, and town supervisor Cyrus Rexford and Hannah Rexford in 1883. Incorporated into its structure was an earlier farmhouse built by Cyrus' ancestor, Edward Rexford.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Four Generations of Family, c. 1895
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Reprint of original photograph showing four generations of the Vischer family. Sitting at far right is Harriet Shepard, 1816-1897, daughter of William Shepard. She and her husband, Francis N. Vischer, lived at Grooms Corners in a house on Miller Road north of the intersection. Harriet's daughter, Huldah Vischer, 1848-1918, is seated on the left. She was the wife of Erastus Forte. Her daughter, Minnie Forte, 1868-1926, is standing. Minnie married Roland J. Wood of Jonesville; their daughter, Alma Wood, 1893-1985, is the child in front. Alma married Elmer Bloodgood, also of Jonesville.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Roland J. Wood House, Main Street, Jonesville, NY, c. 1900
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: April 1995 reprint of an original photograph. Roland J. and Minnie Forte Wood lived in this house at the time the photograph was taken. Their daughter, Alma Wood, married Elmer Bloodgood here. Alma was the brother of long-time Jonesville resident Vernon Wood. The sign on the tree reads "Wiard Plows" and the wagon is loaded with barrels.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Image scanned to remove black border around photograph. Photograph of the Barney House, a farmhouse that stood near the present site of the Clifton Knolls Club House. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James Hicks House, Barney Road and Moe Road, Clifton Park Village, NY, c. 1890
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of the James Hicks House with an unidentified woman standing in front by the fence. The Federal home was build around 1820, and a Palladian window is visible in front. According to the 1851 and 1866 maps, as well as the 1850 census, the home was owned by James and Jane Hicks. The Doty and Fields families were the last owners. The house was destroyed for the development of Clifton Knolls in 1967.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: David Schauber House, Ballston Lake, NY, c. 1900
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Reprint of an original photograph showing the David Schauber House, Old Schauber Road, Ballston Lake. David and Maphlet Budlong Schauber built the house in the northwest corner of town in 1806. David's father had immigrated from Germany to Schenectady. The Schaubers raised twelve children in the house, which remained in the family for 180 years.

From left to right are: unknown, Mr. Odell, Mr. Potter, unknown, Mr. McKenzey (super on the job), Mr. Wendell, and two unknown men. Writing on the bottom of the photograph reads "Contract 17 Erie Canal T.H. Karr Contractor." Scanned image is cropped to remove the white border around the photograph.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Stony Creek Reservoir, near Vischer Ferry, NY, 1952
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph showing the construction of the dam holding back the water of the Stony Creek, creating a reservoir for the Town of Colonie. The Latham Water District purchased the land in Clifton Park in the late 1940s to create the reservoir.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Vischer's Mill, Ferry Drive, Vischer Ferry, NY, c. 1900
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of Vischer's Mill. The mill pictured is thought to be the third mill on this site, with the first mill established by Eldert Vischer at the time of the American Revolution. The mill was taken down around 1950. Scanned image is cropped to remove the white border around the photograph.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Peter's Mill, Vischer Ferry, NY, c. 1890
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of Peter's Mill, build by William Peters in about 1814. It was used as a sawmill, gristmill, and woolen mill. A stone bridge is visible to the right.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ice Cutters on the Mohawk River, c. 1900
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of men harvesting ice on the Mohawk River. Photo is taken from the south side of the river. Scanned image is cropped to remove the white border around the photograph. Caption below the image reads "Ice cutters on the river at Mohawk View (South side of the river). The N. Y. Central R.R. used considerable ice on their trains and used from 20 to 30 local men to cut it and load on their freight cars where it would be delivered to their ice houses. Many of these men came from the Vischer Ferry area.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
